content.description:
Step up to the roof, clip the route's lone bolt, and pull yourself over the roof (crux, kinda fun). Head up and right on 4th class terrain to the anchors for "Cosgrove Face", 5.12a.

Though the roof is fun, "Vixen" is definitely a one-move wonder type of route. Not really worth your time unless you can't climb the other routes at the crag.
content.protection: 1 bolt, two-bolt anchor. You could probably place finger size cams over the roof if you aren't comfortable soloing 4th class.
content.location: On the West (left) face of Lyme Disease Rock, two routes left of Pigs' Feat. Look for a lone bolt just above a small roof.

content.description:
Fun route with unique, dynamic movement. It's a bit contrived in the sense that if you decide to mantle onto the mossy ramp by bolt two instead of staying on the arete, you can avoid the crux. However, this really isn't too tempting because all the holds that are "off" are covered in moss.

The route starts with some balancy slab moves to get established under the second bolt. From here, power up and right through an intricate and gymnastic ascending traverse that requires big moves between large sloping holds. The difficulty backs off after a good rest at the fourth bolt.
content.protection:
4 bolt to a two-bolt anchor

-- the first bolt is kind of sketchy and could use replacement

-- it would be difficult to TR (without directionals) because of the traversing nature of this route
content.location: On the right side of Lyme Disease Rock, the first bolted route uphill of the classic "Ticks Ripped My Flesh", 5.10b. Not as far uphill as "Lucky in Love". Look for bolts that go up and noticeably right on a bulbous arete-like feature.

content.description:
An interesting start leads to the first clip . Climbing up fun jugs on a gently overhanging wall ensues for three more clips to a bolted anchor .

A really fun climb reminiscent of a gym route . Well bolted with a clean airball if you should falter . "Great for running laps" .
content.location: On the east (right) side of the jagged arete .

content.description: Using the same anchor as Ticks Ripped My Flesh, stem and chimney between the tree and the rock face, following the same line as Ticks up the rock. I did this on top rope and had fun with the stemming variations. Could be led with a few draws as well. This is mostly just a fun, playful route variation on Ticks that squeezes some more fun out of this small but delightful crag.
content.protection: 3 bolts to 2 bolt anchor. Anchor accessible from top to set up top rope, but be very careful because there is full exposure on all sides.
content.location: Start at the base of Ticks Ripped My Flesh, and use the tree.

content.description:
Fun, short route.

Clip the first bolt before really doing any climbing, and ooze your way up to the obvious round cobble below the second bolt (this is noticeably easier if you are taller). Make a balancy clip and crank through the powerful, core-intensive crux. A good shake-out at the final bolt allows you to recuperate before committing to the tricky slab moves that guard the anchor.
content.protection: 3 bolts, two-bolt anchor (shared with "Unlucky in Love")
content.location: The furthest uphill (bolted) climb on the East( right) face of Lyme Disease Rock. Right of the  traversing "Unlucky in Love", 5.11b.

content.description:
"Cosgrove Face" is not a particularly inspiring line because it is so short, but it might worthwhile first 5.12 because it is short, well-protected and very reasonable for the grade if you have some good beta. More like a roped boulder problem than anything.

Start on ledge, clip two close bolts, and fire the sequential boulder problem crux, hitting a good horizontal at the third bolt. Make one last slippery mantle move to access easier, mossy terrain and the anchors.

Someone reinforced one of the holds through the crux with glue but maybe shouldn't have bothered because the hold is not strictly necessary.
content.location: On the left face of Lyme Disease rock, just left of "Tick Ripped My Flesh", 5.10b.

content.description:
Start climbing up a very short , yet awkward , dihedral to a big ledge . Move up staying left of the arete . The crux comes near the top where you pull through some sloping dirty holds to bigger jugs above . Bolted anchor for top roping .

Given two stars in the Morris guidebook . A little generous IMO , not nearly as good as 'Ticks ripped my flesh' . Still worth doing for sure .
content.location: The west face of Lyme disease rock . One route right of 'Cosgove Face' (5.12) .

content.description: Can be toproped from the same bolts as Bitch Goddess Left, using the terrain as a directional. Start left of the bulge and pull around, then head straight towards the anchor. Really more of a highball with a sloped landing. As of summer 2018, dirty/mossy from lack of traffic; very short.
content.location: A few feet to the right of Bitch Goddess left.

content.description: Set TR on the anchors to the right of Lucky in Love.
